analyzeResult.content:
L40002
PHILIP MORRIS
04/28/94 08:15 2804 628 6572
THE ISSUE OF NICOTINE AS AN ADDICTIVE OR REINFORCING AGENT
Recent televised US House of Representative Hearings have implicated nicotine as the "addictive" drug in tobacco which "forces" smokers to continue to use our products. The evidence used to prove these allegations involves both good and questionable scientific experiments and medical opinion. Some of the scientific evidence, and most of the medical opinion, claim to conclusively prove that nicotine is a highly addictive drug. These same experiments claim that nicotine, is at least, if not more addictive, than what we normally consider to be drugs of abuse such as cocaine, heroin, morphine and amphetamine. This is interesting, since there is no universally recognized and accepted definition of the effects of an addictive drug. Still, there has been a great deal of scientific research designed to prove that nicotine is just that.
Typically, five conditions have been cited as proof that nicotine found in tobacco functions like the accepted drugs of addiction, These include the assertion, that nicotine is highly addictive to animais, that nicotine produces the same or more intense drug "rush" that addicts obtain from crack cocaine and heroin, that cigarette smokers dose themselves in the same manner as drug addicts, that "addicted" smokers are unable to spontaneously stop smoking, and finally, that the withdrawal symptoms that occur when smokers stop smoking are like those of drugs of abuse. This article will address some of those issues.
There have been many recent ( ** ) and classical studies ( ** ) which have attempted to demonstrate the concept of nicotine-based tobacco addiction. The bulk of these studies have relied upon the use of animals in order to mimic the effects of nicotine in humans. Unfortunately, in order to actually demonstrate the "addictive effects of nicotine", many of the researchers conducting the experiments have been forced to treat the animals with much higher doses of nicotine than smokers could reasonably expect to consume ( ** ). For example, scientifically speaking, the doses of nicotine which have been used, in studies involving a variety of animals from rats to monkeys, generally range from 0.1 - 3 mg nicotine per kg of body weight administered through the blood stream( ** ). However, while smoking one cigarette, the average smoker can only expect to consume between 0.013 to 0.026 mg nicotine per kg of weight ( ** ). To put this into perspective, if a smoker participated as an "animal" in these scientific studies, he would have to smoke at best 4, and at worst, over 230 cigarettes at the same time!
This is particularly evident in the scientific data from two studies in particular. In one of those studies ((((yagitaita (et.al.)(*) researchers had to give 2.650 mg of nicotine per kg of weight to monkeys as a single dose, in order to produce their "addictive effect". This is equivalent to a single dose of 10 packs of cigarettes. In another study (*) involving monkeys, the animals were said to have vomited at the maximum doses of nicotine which they would self-administer (0.1 - 0.3 mg of nicotine per kg of body weight per dose). INTERESTINGLY, THESE SAME MONKEYS WOULD WORK JUST AS HARD FOR A DOSE OF COCATIN 1/10 AS HIGH AS NICOTINE.
Although there are differences in the nature of food and drug reinforcers, both are self-administered (12) .
By
2056139549

paragraphs.content: THE ISSUE OF NICOTINE AS AN ADDICTIVE OR REINFORCING AGENT

Recent televised US House of Representative Hearings have implicated nicotine as the "addictive" drug in tobacco which "forces" smokers to continue to use our products. The evidence used to prove these allegations involves both good and questionable scientific experiments and medical opinion. Some of the scientific evidence, and most of the medical opinion, claim to conclusively prove that nicotine is a highly addictive drug. These same experiments claim that nicotine, is at least, if not more addictive, than what we normally consider to be drugs of abuse such as cocaine, heroin, morphine and amphetamine. This is interesting, since there is no universally recognized and accepted definition of the effects of an addictive drug. Still, there has been a great deal of scientific research designed to prove that nicotine is just that.

Typically, five conditions have been cited as proof that nicotine found in tobacco functions like the accepted drugs of addiction, These include the assertion, that nicotine is highly addictive to animais, that nicotine produces the same or more intense drug "rush" that addicts obtain from crack cocaine and heroin, that cigarette smokers dose themselves in the same manner as drug addicts, that "addicted" smokers are unable to spontaneously stop smoking, and finally, that the withdrawal symptoms that occur when smokers stop smoking are like those of drugs of abuse. This article will address some of those issues.

There have been many recent ( ** ) and classical studies ( ** ) which have attempted to demonstrate the concept of nicotine-based tobacco addiction. The bulk of these studies have relied upon the use of animals in order to mimic the effects of nicotine in humans. Unfortunately, in order to actually demonstrate the "addictive effects of nicotine", many of the researchers conducting the experiments have been forced to treat the animals with much higher doses of nicotine than smokers could reasonably expect to consume ( ** ). For example, scientifically speaking, the doses of nicotine which have been used, in studies involving a variety of animals from rats to monkeys, generally range from 0.1 - 3 mg nicotine per kg of body weight administered through the blood stream( ** ). However, while smoking one cigarette, the average smoker can only expect to consume between 0.013 to 0.026 mg nicotine per kg of weight ( ** ). To put this into perspective, if a smoker participated as an "animal" in these scientific studies, he would have to smoke at best 4, and at worst, over 230 cigarettes at the same time!

This is particularly evident in the scientific data from two studies in particular. In one of those studies ((((yagitaita (et.al.)(*) researchers had to give 2.650 mg of nicotine per kg of weight to monkeys as a single dose, in order to produce their "addictive effect". This is equivalent to a single dose of 10 packs of cigarettes. In another study (*) involving monkeys, the animals were said to have vomited at the maximum doses of nicotine which they would self-administer (0.1 - 0.3 mg of nicotine per kg of body weight per dose). INTERESTINGLY, THESE SAME MONKEYS WOULD WORK JUST AS HARD FOR A DOSE OF COCATIN 1/10 AS HIGH AS NICOTINE.
Although there are differences in the nature of food and drug reinforcers, both are self-administered (12) .
